title: William Shimell
text:
William Shimell (born Brentwood, Essex, 23 September 1952) is an English <a href="baritone">baritone</a> who has had an active international career performing in <a href="opera">opera</a> and on the concert platform since the 1980s, and more recently has appeared in non-singing roles in films.
Biography.
Shimell studied at the <a href="Guildhall%20School%20of%20Music%20and%20Drama">Guildhall School of Music and Drama</a> and at the <a href="National%20Opera%20Studio">National Opera Studio</a>. For his student performance at the Guildhall the "<a href="Opera%20%28British%20magazine%29">Opera</a>" critic noted "William Shimells's Figaro stood out from all the others. His is a rich, full-toned baritone voice, and he used it to great musical and dramatic effect."
He joined the chorus of <a href="Kent%20Opera">Kent Opera</a> in 1978 and sang an usher in "<a href="Rigoletto">Rigoletto</a>" with them in 1980 and "<a href="Venus%20and%20Adonis%20%28opera%29">Venus and Adonis</a>" in the UK and Venice. At Sadler's Wells in 1981 he appeared as Young Scrooge in Musgrave's "Christmas Carol".
He sang Masetto in "<a href="Don%20Giovanni">Don Giovanni</a>" in February 1980 at <a href="London%20Coliseum">London Coliseum</a> for <a href="English%20National%20Opera">English National Opera</a>, going on to sing Gregory in the new production of "<a href="Rom%C3%A9o%20et%20Juliette">Romeo and Juliet</a>" in March 1981 and a Herald in the new production of "<a href="Otello">Otello</a>" in September 1981, and other roles subsequently with the company.
He made his debut at <a href="Glyndebourne%20Opera">Glyndebourne Opera</a> in May 1984 as Count Almaviva, and at <a href="La%20Scala">La Scala</a> in 1991 was Baron Dourlinski in "<a href="Lodo%C3%AFska">Lodoïska</a>". Other opera companies with which he appeared in the earlier part of his career include San Francisco Opera (1988), Frankfurt Opera (1988), Grand Theatre Geneva (1989), Vienna State Opera (1990), Lyric Opera Chicago (1991).
At Covent Garden he made his debut as Schaunard in "La bohème" in 1985, going on to sing in "<a href="Cos%C3%AC%20fan%20tutte">Così fan tutte</a>" (1986 and 1992 – as Guglielmo), "Werther" (1987 – Albert), Capriccio (1991 – Olivier), "La bohème" (1996 – Marcello), "The Rake's Progress" (2010 – Nick Shadow), "Così fan tutte" (2010 – Don Alfonso), and "Manon" (2010 – De Brétigny).
At the Metropolitan Opera in New York Shimell made his debut in "La bohème" in 1996 as Marcello, continuing with "Così fan tutte" (1996 and 2010 – Don Alfonso), "Madama Butterfly" (2000 – Sharpless), "Manon" (2005 – De Brétigny) and "Iphigénie en Tauride" (2007 – Thoas).
With major companies, Shimell has sung the title roles in "<a href="Le%20nozze%20di%20Figaro">Le nozze di Figaro</a>" and "<a href="Don%20Giovanni">Don Giovanni</a>", Papageno, Dandini, and Malatesta.
In 1983 Shimell won the Shell International Opera Prize and he sang at the <a href="Last%20Night%20of%20the%20Proms">Last Night of the Proms</a> in 1984.
In 2008 Shimell was working with Iranian director <a href="Abbas%20Kiarostami">Abbas Kiarostami</a> in a production of "Così fan tutte" at the <a href="Aix-en-Provence%20Festival">Aix-en-Provence Festival</a>, when Kiarostami offered him a non-singing role in a film. Shimell had very little knowledge of cinema, but his fluency in French and Italian helped during filming (the initial script had been translated from <a href="Persian%20language">Persian</a> to French to English). The film, "<a href="Certified%20Copy%20%28film%29">Certified Copy</a>" "(Copie conforme)", was released in 2010. Shimell then took a role in the film "<a href="Amour%20%282012%20film%29">Amour</a>" (2012).
He has appeared on a few audio recordings, including the title role in "Don Giovanni" under <a href="Riccardo%20Muti">Riccardo Muti</a>, <a href="A%20Sea%20Symphony">A Sea Symphony</a> by Vaughan Williams, <a href="Royal%20Liverpool%20Philharmonic%20Orchestra">Royal Liverpool Philharmonic Orchestra</a>, <a href="Vernon%20Handley">Vernon Handley</a>, <a href="Mass%20in%20B%20minor">Mass in B minor BWV232</a> by JS Bach, Summer's last will and testament by <a href="Constant%20Lambert">Lambert</a>, Funeral cantata on the death of Emperor Joseph II, and "<a href="Pulcinella%20%28ballet%29">Pulcinella</a>".
